did.abstract: Though the Miscellaneous Manuscripts collection is composed of items that do not fall readily into any other existing collection, the two dominant intellectual areas represented in the collection are Early American History and History of Science.
did.physloc: Copies of Native American images from Catlin, Parsons, McKenney, Speck and Boas for research purposes are housed in the sub-basement.
LH-MV-D-11; LH-MV-C-9 (George III, 14 May 1783, OS); LH-SB-Black Case-8 (OS: [1777] Turkish doc.; 1809 Tilesius. Skeleton Mammoth); LH-SB-Black Case-13-14 (OS); LH-SB-XOS Case 1-3 (XOS)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous Manuscripts collection is composed of items that do not fall readily into other collections. The two dominant intellectual areas represented in the collection are early American history and the history of science.

In the collection there are letters by, and material relating to, James Madison, Benjamin Franklin, William and Thomas Penn, Horatio Gates, John Hancock, Pierre Eugene du Simitiere, William Pitt, the U. S. Continental Congress, Benedict Arnold, George Washington, General Lafayette, Albert Gallatin. Also of interest is James Logan’s “Questionnaire used basis of testimony in the Penn-Maryland boundary dispute,” and George III’s 1783 Commission to David Hartley to negotiate peace with the thirteen United States.

Additionally, the collection holds a variety of material about the French and Indian War, the American Revolution, and non-importation resolutions. There is also such items as a petition to John Adams from “sundry female inhabitants of Philadelphia” asking for the release of prisoners from Fries Rebellion (1799); Jared Sparks correspondence concerning the publication of the Franklin Letters; and a facsimile of Lee’s General Order No. 9, surrendering the Army of Northern Virginia (April 10, 1865).

In the history of science, the collection holds letters by, and material relating to, many of the big names in science, especially natural philosophers of the 18th century but including scientists through into the 1930s. Among those represented are Johannes Fredericus Gronovious, John Bartram, Horace-Bénédict de Saussure, Pierre Eugène Du Simitière, William Herschel, William Dunbar, James Rumsey and the Rumsian Society, Sir Joseph Banks, Jean Baptiste de Lamarck, James Edward Smith, Charles L. Bonaparte, Sir David Brewster, William Buckland, George Cuvier, Michael Faraday, Louis Agassiz, Edward Hitchcock, Benjamin Silliman, Charles Wilkes, Elisha Kent Kane, John Tyndall, Francis Trevelyan Buckland, Thomas Edison, Lord Kelvin, Nikola Tesla, Max Born and Max Planck.

Also included is material related to the Bristol Institution; a letter asking Lord Kelvin permission to use "Kelvin" as measurement for electricity (May 3, 1892); a letter signed by Albert Einstein, from Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists, asking for money to educate the public about the responsibility of atomic energy; Neils Bohr’s “Challenge to Civilization”; letters concerning the development of physics and atomic energy, answering questions from E. Chudzicki. Together this material highlights the emerging fields of geology, astronomy, physics, natural history, ornithology, botany, chemistry and genetics.

Native American Images note : Nearly 200 black and white silver gelatin photographs, negatives, slides, and photomechanical prints of Iroquois chiefs, signatures, scenes of the Isleta pueblo, Ojibwa portraits, Penobscot attire, and Baffinland Inuits. Copies of images from Catlin, Parsons, McKenney, Speck and Boas are found. Of note, pictographs of Iroquois signatures are represented by symbols of hatchets, deer, turtles, arrows, and pipes. Each name is identified with the date of the signing of various eighteenth century treaties. Referenced in Freeman’s Guide to manuscripts relating to the American Indian, number 1644.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Inventory not complete, material dated after 1978 is not uncataloged. For additional information on these items, see the in-house shelf list.

odd.head: Naval History Note
odd.p: There are numerous items in this collection which may be of interest to students of naval history:

list.head: Barry, John, 1745-1803.
list.item: United States, Continental Congress. Letter to John Barry. 1776 April 11. Relative to prize sloop Edward. 1 page.

list.head: Byrd, Richard Evelyn, 1888-1957.
list.item: Byrd, Richard Evelyn. Letter to Mrs. Anna Lane Lingelbach. 1950 April 5. Appeal to help save people in Soviet concentration camps. 1 item.

list.head: Humphreys, Joshua, 1751-1838.
list.item: Humphreys, Joshua. Letterbook, with letters to Tench Francis, Thomas Truxton, etc. pertaining to ships for the navy. 1797 August - 1797 November. Correspondence. 7 pages.

list.head: Jones, John Paul, 1747-1792.
list.item: Jones, John Paul. Letter to General William Whipple. 1777 December 11. Reporting on trip of the Ranger, refers to U. S. commissioners. 3 pages.
Jones, John Paul. Letter to Robert Morris. 1779 October 13. News of his activities including the battle between the Bon Homme Richard and the Serapis on September 23, mentions Dr. Franklin. 4 pages.

list.head: Maury, Matthew Fontaine, 1806-1873.
list.item: Maury, Matthew Fontaine. Letter to Naval School of Philadelphia. 1843 January 17. Thanking for information. 1 page.
Fitzroy, Robert. Letter to W. Hepworth Dixon. 1860 November 29. Will review Matthew Fontaine Maury's work. 4 pages.
Fitzroy, Robert. Letter to W. Hepworth Dixon. 1860 December 17. Concerning his review of Matthew Fontaine Maury. 3 pages.

list.head: Paulding, James Kirke, 1778-1860.
list.item: Paulding, James Kirke. Letter to John Vaughan. 1839 March 18. Enclosing new plan for keeping log book at sea, by Captain E. Beaufort of the British Admiralty. 1 page.
Poinset, Joel R. Letter to John Vaughan. 1839 June 28. Encloses note from James Kirke Paulding. Hopes to visit Philadelphia by the end of July. Mr. Sully in Washington. 2 pages.

list.head: United States. Navy.
list.item: Barton, William P. C. Letter to C. H. Stedman. 1842 January 1. Concerning J. Francis Tuckerman and his examination for the U.S. Navy. 2 pages.
Barton, William P. C. Letter to Jacob Bigelow. 1842 January 7. Concerning J. Francis Tuckerman and his examination for the U.S. Navy. 2 pages.
Barton, William P. C. Letter to J. Francis Tuckerman. 1842 January 7. Concerning his treatment by members of the board and how he [Barton] has answered them at the naval board. 3 pages.
Hamilton, Harry D. Concerning the ships named Franklin. 1948 July 3. Concerning the ships named Franklin. 5 pages.

list.head: United States Naval Observatory.
list.item: Abbe, Cleveland. Letter to H. F. Peters. 1890 January 7. Astronomy, and proposal to rotate superintendency of the U.S. Naval Observatory. 3 pages.

list.head: Wilkes, Charles, 1798-1877. United States Exploring Expedition (1838-1842).
list.item: Poinsett, Joel Roberts. Letter to Mahlon Dickerson. 1837 January 7. Wishes William Davis appointed to serve on the United States Exploring Expedition. 2 pages.
Wilkes, Charles. Letter to Thomas Ap Catesby Jones. 1837 July 1. Concerning the Wilkes expedition (United States Exploring Expedition), use of India Rubber. 2 pages.
Paulding, James Kirke. Letter to Lieutenant Charles Wilkes. 1838 July 3. Encloses letters from Mr. N. L. Lee, who is soliciting appointment as carpenter. 1 page.
Peale, Titian Ramsay. Letter to Robert M. Patterson. 1838 November 13. Life aboard the Peacock on the United States Exploring Expedition. 3 pages.
Peale, Titian Ramsay. Letter to to John K. Kane. 1840 April 5. Accounts of adventures with United States Exploring Expedition. Discovery of Antarctic Continent. 4 pages.
Jay, John C. Letter to Benjamin Tappan. 1843 February 8. Applies to work on shells brought back by Wilkes Expedition (United States Exploring Expedition). 2 pages.
Prime, Frederick. Letter to Joseph L. Tillinghast. 1843 February 11. Recommends Mr. Jay as conchologist to report on specimens returned to Wilkes. 2 pages.

Peale, Titian Ramsay. Letter to George Ord. 1843 March 14. Complains of the manner in which members of the late Exploring Expedition (the United States Exploring Expedition) were treated upon return. 2 pages.

Peale, Titian Ramsay. Letter to George Ord. 1844 November 26. Forwards newspaper containing Senator Tappan's Plan for the investment of the Smithsonian bequest. Related to the United States Exploring Expedition. 2 pages.
Ord, George. Letter to Titian R. Peale. 1844 December 4. Hopes the American Philosophical Society will receive a copy of Captain Wilkes' book. 3 pages.
Peale, Titian Ramsay. Letter to George Ord. 1845 April 7. Introducing Mr. William Rich, botanist of the late United States Exploring Expedition. 1 page.
Ord, George. Letter to Titian R. Peale. 1845 May 20. Concerning identity of a partridge. Charles Wilkes has promised the American Philosophical Society a copy of his work. 2 pages.

Peale, Titian Ramsay. Letter to George Ord. 1845 July 3. May present himself for appointment as superintendent of National Gallery if Captain Wilkes of the late United States Exploring Expedition resigns or is removed. 3 pages.
Ord, George. Letter to Titian R. Peale. 1845 December 21. Has "not read a page" of Wilkes' Narrative. 4 pages.
Dana, James Dwight. Letter to Charles Wilkes. 1848 October 3. Is working on the geological report and the marine crustacea. 1 page.

Ord, George. Letter to Titian R. Peale. 1852 January 27. "I have been long persuaded there was a plot concocted to defraud you of the produce of your labors" in connection to the United States Exploring Expedition. 4 pages.
Ord, George. Letter to Titian R. Peale. 1852 December 4. Injustice of treatment accorded to Mr. Peale in connection with his work on the United States Exploring Expedition. 3 pages.
Wilkes, Charles. Letter to William Pitt Fessenden. 1857 February 20. Concerns the publication of the information collected during the United States Exploring Expedition of 1838-1842. 4 pages.
Tennessee Historical Society. Letter to Charles Wilkes. 1857 September 2. Certificate of election to the Tennessee Historical Society. 1 page.

New York (N.Y.), Common Council. Letter to Captain Charles Wilkes, U.S.N. 1861 November 25. Granting the freedom of the city to Captain Charles Wilkes for his service in the capture of Mason and Slidell. 1 page.
New York (N.Y.), Common Council. Letter to Captain Charles Wilkes, U.S.N. 1861 November 25. Resolutions adopted upon the capture of Mason and Slidell. 2 pages.
O'Connell, Maurice, Sir. Letter to Captain Charles Wilkes. Tuesday morning. He and lady O'Connell accept invitation. 1 page.

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: J. Stephen Catlett wrote of the Miscellaneous Manuscripts collection that “there is no other way to describe these manuscript letters, essays, and other papers that are contained presently in 49 boxes.” Catlett then listed a random assortment of names of authors found in the collection. Each individual item was catalogued in the card catalogue, but his data has now been put online. Rather than try to replicate that data, this entry will focus on some of the main themes of the collection and some of the most notable documents.

Among the many singular items are a letter by John Locke (in French); a letter by Isaac Newton; a receipt of Josiah Franklin's; letters by William Pitt; a letter from Patience Lovell Wright, a sculptor turned spy for the Americans during the Revolution (although the letter predates Independence, it does show her support for the colonies); and notes by and letters to Crevecoeur.
There is also a heretofore unpublished essay on the reasons for and a detail of the Albany plan of union.

The collection also contains interesting odds and ends, such as the story of John Kinsey’s death and the strange circumstances surrounding it in which he had a detailed premonition of his demise the night before. Also of note is a letter from one of Deborah Franklin’s cousins that relates the birth of Deborah's son in 1768.

The collection also has a heavy focus on Pennsylvania and Philadelphia history, especially in the early period. There are some early and official documents, such as an original William Penn grant to Thomas Powell. Some of these documents are potentially research-rich, such as the alphabetical listing of all grants of land in the colony from 1682-1698 and a list of the lots in Philadelphia granted from 1682-1692 that also has a partial sketch of Mulberry and Sassafras Streets. There is also what may be one of the first drafts of Philadelphia’s charter and the finished official charters of Philadelphia and Chester. There is a fair amount on colonial politics, especially in the correspondence of James Logan.
In addition, there are many wills, various bonds, some inventories and surveys, and legal documents on the care of orphans.

There is also an interesting series of Benjamin Rush’s letters written in 1768 that touch on affairs of the heart and make mention of Rush’s support for the colonies in their struggles with the “Mother Country.”

The Revolutionary era documents include letters from William Strahan to David Hall that supplement the APS’s Hall and Strahan collections. The letters often touch on political matters, including Strahan’s belief that nonimportation was an ineffective means of protest. A significant number of other items touch on Revolution-era activities and circumstances.

For the post-War period, there is a fascinating narrative of a rebellion in Lewistown, Pennsylvania in 1790 that involved a judge. There is also a notebook by Jonathan Donath on beekeeping that is identical to the other one in the APS collection, although this one appears to be the original and includes a reference to George Washington and others visiting Donath's apiary during the Constitutional Convention. This period also has a number of letters from Thomas FitzSimmons, a prominent Philadelphia politician and one of the only Catholic signers of the Constitution.
There is also a remarkable petition from female residents of Philadelphia requesting those held in Philadelphia jails because of Fries Rebellion be released.
For the nineteenth century, the collection shifts toward material about science and about the Philadelphia elite.

Included in the scientific material are notes, letters, notebooks, and meteorological diaries. There are also a series of records relating to the transportation revolution, including notes from Loammi Baldwin and canal engineering, and numerous letters regarding steam boats and internal improvements.

The Vaughan family have a heavy presence in the collection, though almost all material from John was in 2010 removed to a separate collection. Miscellaneous Manuscripts also has a series of Matthew Carey correspondence.

One of the more noteworthy themes of the collection is of people writing about history and historical memory. There is a fascinating translation of letters from an unnamed Frenchman who describes the histories of various colonies and the American Revolution from his perspective. There are records of Lafayette’s visit to US in 1824-1825. The collection also has an large number of notes from Moredcai Jacobs in which he adds his own memory of events and places depicted in John Watson’s Annals of Philadelphia. Finally, there are many letters from Jared Sparks seeking letters and documents on Benjamin Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plan of attack, with map and written directions. Proposal for attack on Kittanning, an Indian town near Shippensburg, Pennsylvania, by Armstrong, based upon a report by "John Baker Soldier at Fort Shierley, who last Winter made his escape from the Indians at the Kittanning." The attack was made in 1756; Kittanning was taken and burned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Annotated: "A.B. two Pieces surveyed to Snyder (who is now contented) in pursuance of his Warrent dated 30th April 1765 for 50.00.
"C. Sur[veyed] to Moyer in pursuance of his Application No. 1318, dated 30 Jan[uar]y 1766, altho' not the very Spot mentioned in his Description;-

"Note. Mr. Miller wrote me a Letter, in which he mentions the Opinion of Mr. Tilghman, concerning the above Lands & that the Secretary desir'd him to write(?) to me that it was his Opinion, which allows Moyer his g[ ]ns, & Snyder the Land in two Pieces adj[oinin]g his old [tenet?].

scopecontent.p: Ipswich, A.L.S. 2p., add. Speaks of his collecting "about 40 different species of our sea shells, some of them very rare & curious." Expresses hope of seeing his correspondent soon. Mentions Pickering.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Baltimore] A.L.S. 2p. and add., end. Relates to Rubens and Rembrandt Peale and the museum in Baltimore.

did.unittitle: Letter to Dr. John Kearsley Mitchell;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 3p. and add. Remarks on physics, geology, medicine; his war with the clergy; discusses Featherstonehaugh, Lyell, Broussais; mentions Silliman, the Franklin Institute, the National Gazette, etc.

did.unittitle: Letter to the Président de la Société geographique à Paris;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paris, L. 3p. Copy. In French. Concerning Mexican antiquities, with especial reference to those in the APS. Refers to Poinsett, Humboldt and DuPonceau

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paris. L.S.: B.G. Cuvier, C. Dumeril, and L. Corier. 2p. and end. In French. Concerning fossil bones. Makes Harlan a Correspondant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paris, L.S.: L[ouis] Cordier. Cuvier and Cruzier 1p.with reply in Barbé Marbois' hand in draft form in margin. In French. Thanks him for gift of materials to the museum.

did.unittitle: Mode of extracting linseed and sunflower oil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ----, 2 pp. and endorsement. Printed in American Farmer, Baltimore, November 18, 1831.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 1p. and add. envelope. Wishes the letter by Jefferson which he will not use in the proposed edition of the letter of Thomas Jefferson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p.,add. Xerox copy. (from the original in the possession of the Linnean Society, London.) Thanks for acorns. Lists cuttings for fruit trees and vines being shipped to the U.S. Presented by Edmund Berkeley; July 22, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Walton Hall, A.L.S. 1p., add., end. Refers to the controversy with Cobbett resulting from Waterton's paper on tithes. Mentions Blackstone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed L.filled in in ms.S.: Will[ia]m Hamilton. 1p.and add. Notification of election to membership. Presented by Mr. Sol Feinstone; 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Walton Hall, A.L.S. 1p., add. Informs Bancks that the "Telescope has arrived quite safe; and indeed it does you credit, for it is a most excellent one".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p.and add.,end. Concerning publication in press and idenfication of one species.

did.unittitle: Rich[ar]d C. Taylor to G.W. Featherstonhaugh,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tioga, [Pa.], 1 p., address and endorsement. A.L.S. Regarding his cabinet of fossils.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 1p. Offers to give his opinion about certain drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hallowell, 2 pp. L. Copy. Has received roots of meadow saffron from Petty Vaughan. Wishes the same distributed with care. Use and nature of the plant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. In French. Introduces Mr. LeBoucher of Caen, asks to let him study in the museum. Concerns problems of inheritance of estate.

did.unittitle: Letter to Charles Konig, secretary of the Royal Society of London;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paris, A.L.S. 2p. and add. In French. Sends copies of various papers he has written. Presented by Dr. Gilbert Chinard, April 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. To curator of Bristol Institution. Makes arrangements for delivery of pictures purchased as Exhibition. Reports on shell shops in Torquy and dredging activity in area. Asks for microscope and Sowerby's Genera of shells.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ----, 1 p. A.L.S. Reasons for the resignation of [Archbishop?] Leighton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. Thanks for tortoise shell. Explains how he did not know who sent it to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: London, A.L.S. 1p.and add.,end. Cannot visit Cambridge this season.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 3p. and add. Asks permission to publish Benjamin Franklin letters in his possession. Mr. Vaughan will forward material. FILM54-61 FRAME218

did.unittitle: Letter to Sir John [F. W.] Herschel;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 1p. and add. Asks Herschel to send his manuscript as soon as possible "to enable me to publish your 'Astronomy' on 1st April." Mentions Southey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S.: R. Hunter. 1p.and add. Forwards volume 14 of the Memoirs. (Removed from Royal Irish Academy Transactions, vol.14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 2p. and add., end. Acknowledges receipt of volume containing Franklin letters. Desires information relative to Franklin's family. FILM 54-58 FRAME 168

did.unittitle: Agreement with Franklin Bache and Daniel B. Smith concerning copyright of The Dispensatory of the U.S.A.;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: D.S.: George B. Wood, et al. 2p.and end. Presented by Miss Sarah A. G. Smith; Nov. 9, 1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 1p. and add., end. Acknowledges receipt of information relative to the Franklin family. Mentions a collection of letters from Franklin to Mrs. Mecom. FILM54-58 FRAME 165
Not Found: 1/18/2011

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photo.of D.S. 4p. Certified copy. (from original in Phila. Recorder of Deeds Office.) Presented by Mrs. Frances H. Sousser, 3/4/54.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 1p. [To J.S. Miller, of Bristol Institution.] Encloses a few more prospectuses of new work [Geology of the South-East of England, 1833]. Asks that names of subscribers in Bristol be sent to Longman. Details about impressions of plates, esp. plate of new "fossil animal".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 1p. Sends proof of engraving of the Planets and wants his comments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 1p. and add., end. Has returned the volume containing Franklin letters. The printed volume is to be published in May; will present copy. FILM54-58 FRAME 166
Not Found: 1/18/2011

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Neuchatel, A.L.S. 3p.and add. In German. Wishes to exchange examples of fresh water fishes, fossils. Mineralogy.

did.unittitle: Statement and receipt to Mr. Watts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 3p. (2 Blank). Located in Vault: 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paris, A.L.S: A. Jarry de Mancy 2p. In French (letterhead carries the Society's medal depicting Montyon and Franklin) Notification that the Society is preparing to publish an engraving of Oberkampf after the portrait by Gérard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cambridge, A.L.S. 2p. and add., end. Trusts that he has received a copy of Dr. Franklin's Letters. Volume contains extracts from several letters to Mrs. Mecom in the possession of a Mrs. Loring; disposition of that collection. FILM 54-58 FRAME 167

did.unittitle: Letter to Aaron Alba, Knoxville, Pa.;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. add. Inquiring about land, agriculture, population of Deerfield and Chatham townships. Sending "copper plum" for planting.

did.unittitle: Letter to [Karl Konrad Friedrich Wilhelm] Lachmann, Berlin;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copenhagen, A.L.S. 2p.and add. In Danish(?). Concerning publications of the Copenhagen K.Danske Videnskabernes Selskab.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, 1 p. and address. A.L.S. Introducing Montagu Parker, "an English gentleman ... He desires to inform himself of the Institutions of Your beautiful city."

did.unittitle: Letters to Alexander Catlin Twining, West Point;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4 pieces. Various sizes. Regarding publication of theory of cosmic origin of meteors (Amer. Journ. of Science and Art, v. XXVI, no. 2, 1834). Questions about theory itself. Mentions Silliman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 3p. and add. Contains a note in the hand of Sparks. Relative to the papers of Benjamin Franklin. FILM54-61 FRAME219

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: D.S. 5p. Parchment. Presented by Goodspeed's Book Shop; Dec. 1970. See oversize.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Walton Hall, A.L.S. 3p.and add. Advice on travelling to the spas of Europe. Advice on travelling in Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jardin des Plantes, A.L.S. 3p.and add. In French. Botanical matters. Refers to Des Fontaines.

did.unittitle: Letter to Aaron Alba, Knoxville, Pa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. add. Concerns article he is writing about Deerfield township.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 1p. From Athenaem [of London]. Has not received invitation to dinner. Aquaintance "about on the brink of death." Mentions Royal Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 3p. add.

did.unittitle: Letter to Gen. Joseph G. Swift, Geneva, N.Y.;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lowell, Mass., A.L.S. 3p.and add. Xerox copy. Birth of his son. Will build a locomotive based on an English one. Friendly letter. Presented by Arthur H. Frazier; Jan. 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paris, A.L.S. 4p. In French. Concerning experiments on heat and on galvanism.

did.unittitle: Letter to B[enjamin] H[orner] Coates, Philadelphia;

scopecontent.p: Lexington, Ky., A.L.S. 3p.and add., end. Concerning his ideas on the origin of the Indian. Caldwell cites B.S.Barton's lectures in refuting them.

did.unittitle: Letter to Ed[ward Turner] Bennett, London;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 3p.and add.,end. Forwards sketch of fossil plant and comments on it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.p: Michilimackinac, A.L.S. 1p. Wishes to know if they will print his projected volumes on the Indians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Neuchatel, A.L.S. 3p. In French. Concerning geology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Philadelphia, A.L.S. 3p.and add.,end. Contests the printing of his "Tabular View of Madrid" without permission or his Report.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oxford, A.L.S. 3p., enclosures wanting. Is forwarding two notices on the sloth one of which Buckland wrote. Expresses his enjoyment over meeting Waterton last autumn and invites him to his home. Also asks Waterton to correct him on any errors made in his notice on the sloth. Mentions Agassiz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nahville. Xerox of A.L.S. 3p. Need for Western Academy of Natural Sciences to be "properly conducted." Difficulties of such institution in Philadelphia with APS, etc. Fossils of mollusks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. Will write the hydrodynamics. Concerning Lardners' work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Thanking his correspondent for a gift to the Museum's collection and at the same time offering him a collection of birds, mainly from the African Interior, for his studies. He hope to benefit other collections in other countries as far as he can, and at the same time gives a list of desiderata for his own musuem, including some American animals, insectivores, nests, etc. St. Hilaire refers to his hopes of exchanges of wanted objects between his museum and the Washington Institute [Smithsonian?].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Identifies Old Fort Allen, built by Benjamin Franklin, at Gnadenhuetten in 1756. McConomy says his identification is the "probable site" on Franklin and Allen Streets, near the Lehigh River in the "n.w. corner Weissport Borough." This map accompanies a sketch of the fort and an article on the fort by Rev. John A. McConomy.
